speaker: Alice
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

speaker: Neil
text: … And I'm Neil.

speaker: Alice
text: Can you do any impersonations, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: How about this one: My name is Michael Caine. Not a lot of people know that.

speaker: impersonation
text: Michael Caine, one of our best loved actors here in Britain. Not bad, Neil. And is a very good way to start today's show. We are talking about impersonation – or the act of pretending to be somebody else. Why do we like impersonations, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, sometimes the impersonator is a comedian and doing it to be funny. But another reason is that we get the opportunity to meet people who are no longer with us – like Elvis Presley or Marilyn Monroe. Either way, it helps if it's a good impersonation.

speaker: cheesy
text: Yes, some impersonations are pretty cheesy – and that means bad quality.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yeah so… uh-huh… OK, Alice, I have a question for you!

speaker: Alice
text: Neil, that's terrible!

speaker: Neil
text: Elvis, please, come on. Can you tell me the name of a musical act that impersonates a famous group? Is it …

speaker: Neil
text: a) tribute,

speaker: Neil
text: b) tribune,

speaker: Neil
text: or c) tribunal?

speaker: Alice
text: I'll go for a) tribute.

speaker: Neil
text: A tribute act? OK, well, we'll find out if you got that right later on in the show. But, Alice, don't you think some impersonators start to believe they really are the personalities they imitate?

speaker: Alice
text: What makes you say that?

speaker: Neil
text: Just think: every time you appear as Elvis Presley, you get fans yelling, 'Elvis, Elvis, we love you, Elvis!' And after a while that boundary between you and the real Elvis starts to blur. It must be quite tempting to, you know, pretend that you're the king of rock'n'roll…

speaker: imitate
text: I'm not convinced, Neil. I think Elvis hangs up his wig and moves on. So let's move on too, and talk about the art of imitation. Here's British impressionist Jon Culshaw providing some tips on how to imitate – or copy – people.

speaker: INSERT
text: Jon Culshaw, impressionist

speaker: INSERT
text: Don't just say the catchphrase, don't just say, 'I am Michael Caine.' Say a bit more, get some gags going, some conversation going. Notice the things which are worth stretching, which are worth exaggerating to really give you the caricature of that person. It might be a little tic, it might be a little nuance - whatever you notice first really.

speaker: catchphrase
text: Jon Culshaw, there. What's a catchphrase, Neil?

speaker: gags
text: It's a well-known phrase, often associated with a famous person – like the one I used for Michael Caine earlier on! 'Not a lot of people know that.' So Jon is saying that it isn't enough to repeat a catchphrase or use another impersonator's ideas – you need to think of your own gags – or jokes.

speaker: tic
text: And you do this by noticing and then exaggerating a person's tics. A tic is something you do often without realizing you're doing it, like using certain phrases or gestures – for example, scratching your head. Or in your case, Neil, wiggling your eyebrows.

speaker: Neil
text: Do I wiggle my eyebrows?

speaker: impostors
text: You're doing it right now! But moving on, there is a serious and very negative side to impersonation. Some impostors – or people who deceive others by pretending to be somebody else – pose as doctors or lawyers, for example.

speaker: Neil
text: You mean without having the qualifications to do the job?

speaker: Alice
text: Exactly – which can have serious consequences, for example pretending to be a doctor with no medical knowledge.

speaker: Neil
text: Like in the film with Leonardo DiCaprio where his character impersonates an airline pilot, a doctor, and a lawyer.

speaker: Alice
text: DiCaprio's character in the movie Catch Me If You Can is actually based on a real man called Frank Abagnale. Pan Am estimated that in two years Abagnale flew 250 flights to 26 countries.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, let's listen to Dr Naftali G. Berrill, a forensic psychologist in New York City. He evaluates people for the American government. Here he's talking about another real case of a woman in the US who was caught pretending to be an attorney – that's a lawyer.

speaker: Dr Naftali G. Berrill, forensic psychologist in New York City
text: The thing that was most troubling is that because she realized that she was not an attorney and that she was taking people's money under false pretence, there was no sense of remorse or sense of sadness that she had exploited the people that trusted her. But, you know, in cases where you get these impostors who specifically are pursuing financial gain, they know what they're doing, but they do it with the shallow conscience of an antisocial personality.

speaker: remorse
text: That was Dr Naftali G. Berrill. What does remorse mean, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: It means being sorry for something you've done.

speaker: conscienceshallow
text: And our conscience is our inner sense of right or wrong – so a shallow conscience is one that isn't very deep.

speaker: Antisocial
text: Antisocial in this context means harmful to other people and to society – although in a general sense, it means not enjoying the company of others.

speaker: Alice
text: OK. Well, I love your company, Neil, as you know. Now, how about the answer to today's quiz question?

speaker: Neil
text: I asked: What's the name we use for a band that impersonates a famous group? Is it … a) tribute? b) tribune? Or c) tribunal?

speaker: Alice
text: I said tribute.

speaker: Neil
text: And you were right!

speaker: Alice
text: Hurray!

speaker: Neil
text: Many tribute acts copy the singing style and the appearance of the group as well as playing their music. They often name themselves based on the original band's name (sometimes with a pun), or on one of their songs or albums. For example, Bjorn Again – a famous Abba tribute band. This name is a pun on 'Bjorn', a member of Abba, and the phrase 'Born Again', which means to come back to life!

speaker: Alice
text: OK. It's time to hear the words we learned today. They are:

speaker: Neil
text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon! [Imitates Elvis again.]

speaker: Alice
text: Bye bye.

speaker: Neil
text: Elvis is leaving the studio!
